item.description:
Greene Rose Heritage Park has a grass area which is a really good place to play, you can even do it barefoot!, and when it gets dark, there's still some orange light that can let you play for some extra time.

Players should hopefully fulfill this level: firm understanding of game strategy, with a varied grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting; at least good in one), know the differences between the type of touches to do to the ball (and when to do them) and willing to do all the time the 3-touch dance (in order to achieve a spike at the end: pass, set, spike). If you notice that your level is a bit below other players, don't be afraid to ask for pointers. If you notice that you are slightly above other players, be helpful by pointing out tips.

Access by T: Central Square stop or Kendall square stop. Go to Harvard street or Broadway, and you'll find it quickly.

Recommendation: bring bottles of water, or you will die by thirst while playing :D (especially the sunny days)

Some rules that we usually like to follow (but may change if there is consensus, of course):
- Rally scoring (there's point for your team even if you didn't serve).
- If the ball touches the net while serving, it's a valid point.
- We usually play sets of 25 points. At the end of the set, we exchange fields or mix teams (to try to make them more equivalent).
- Every part of the body is valid to touch the ball.
- Blocks don't count as touches for the touch count (3).
- You cannot do a direct hit (from the net, as in a block) as a reception to the service.
- When it's a set point for the team that serves, it has to be a "jump serve".
- One of each team is normally selected as the setter (normally the one in the middle-up position, next to the net). Teammates should try to pass the ball to her so as she hits the 2nd touch to set. If no one calls the ball and the setter doesn't request "help", the setter is supposed to do the 2nd by default (as in, in case of doubt). [This is not a rule, but a good practice.]
- If the ice-cream van appears, it's not allowed to go for ice cream if you don't bring for your teammates as well. [This is the most important and official rule.]

SO LET'S HAVE SOME FUN!!

(If there are more than 12 people for a net, up to 14 people can play if 2 of them wait outside of the field for their position to be taken by rotation of the team. If we are more than 14, we will split by teams and play 15-point sets.)
item.name: 1 net at Greene Rose Heritage Park
